Award.AwardTitle: REU in Extremal Graph Theory and Dynamical Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF-REU Site in Extremal Graph Theory and Dynamical Systems at the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) will actively engage ten students in each of the summers 2014, 2015, and 2016 in a research experience in mathematics. Research projects will be in the areas of graph theory and dynamical systems, some of which are linked to mathematical biology. Projects will include both applied and theoretical topics. Applied projects will include development and analysis of functional connectivity models of the human brain, and modeling of cardiac arrhythmia. Projects with a theoretical focus will include problems from extremal graph theory, graph labeling, and delay differential equations.

All students will work directly with RIT faculty for the entirety of the program and will receive mentoring in mathematical research practices, as well as in written and oral communication. The program will have a heavy emphasis on networking with other mathematicians and will include a "Researcher in Residence," where an expert from outside of our university visits the program and works with the students. Results from research projects will be disseminated through publications in refereed journals, presentations at national and regional mathematical meetings, and at the students' home institutions. Students will be encouraged to pursue graduate studies and employment in the mathematical sciences. During the program students will participate in an Ethics in Science Workshop. The REU program will intersect with RIT's Summer Mathematics Institute where each of the REU students will present to more than 50 mathematics high school teachers from New York State. The recruitment efforts will target students from universities, liberal arts colleges, and community colleges. The PI aims to have 80 percent of the participants from outside of the host institution, with an emphasis on drawing students from colleges without Ph.D. programs or have limited research opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-REU Program in Extremal Graph Theory and Dynamical Systems at the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) engaed students and faculty in cutting edge research projects in the areas of discrete mathematics and mathematical biology. The program was deemed successful by feedback from students and interviews and reports by an evaluator from outside RIT.

 

Intellectual Merit

The projects ranged from applied projects involving analysis of heart arrhythmias and functional connectivity of the human brain to theoretical projects involving graph ramsey theory and vertex labelling. Students were advised in conducting research and communication of their results, and also participated in an Ethics in Science Workshop. 

Broader Impacts

The program engaged 33 undergraduate students and 6 faculty in mathematical research. Research was disseminated through several publications in mathematical journals, and at professional conferences where 30 of the students presented their research findings at the annual Joint Mathematics Meetings. In addition, REU students gave presentations on their expriences in pursuing undergraduate degrees in STEM majors to area high school mathematics teachers through the Rochester Institute of Technology / Toyota Applied Mathematics Institute. While many of the participants are still undergraduates, most of the students that have graduated have either pursued graduate studies or have sought employment in STEM fields.
